instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, No green light smc issue?
threads.message:
Hi there,
this is liquid damaged board. So far this is what I diagnosed.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. -8.4V
<SIGNAL>PP3V4S_G3H</SIGNAL> -3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> -3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> -3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> -3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> -0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V


THERE IS NO SHORT IN <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> AND PP3V42 IN DIOD MODE.

SMC not heating at all even if you plug for hours.

How should i check whether the SMC getting power?

appriciate if you can help me out.

Thank you,

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, No green light smc issue?
threads.message:
Look up what <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> look like on any old Unibody board - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, etc. Then look at the DC in board of the air and find those same two ICs on the Macbook Air DC in board.

The Macbook Air has the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC on the DC in board itself, not the board, which is why I need you to know <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> look like so you can spot them on the Air's DC in board. Is <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> making its way to the DC in board? Can you measure <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> on pin 5 of <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> at 3v on pins 1/2? If not, how do the <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> pins look on J9500? How do the pins on the DC in cable, the 821-1722 look?

If that's all good, then we keep looking. One thing troubling is <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> being low. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> comes from <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>. <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> tells <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> to turn on and create <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. Is <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> present? If not this can point to a bad SMC.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, No green light smc issue?
threads.message:
Hi Louis, Thank you verymuch for getting back to me. 

<CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/<CHIP>U6901</CHIP> all the power rails are present and accurate as you described.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 0V. <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is 0V.

PLEASE ADVICE ME. 

Thanks Louis.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, No green light smc issue?
threads.message: This all points to a bad SMC. Replace the SMC with one from a donor board, a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, No green light smc issue?
threads.message: Thank you very muh louis. I will do that and update you.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, No green light smc issue?
threads.message:
HI LOUIS,

JUst to update you after replacing SMC the macbook works fine. Thank you verymuch for your guidance. I have an small issue I bought a SMC stencil and solder paste from you. I think I'm doing something wrong way as stencil stick to the SMC and it was a nightmare to reball the SMC. I watched your SMC reball video few times and want to know do we have to put flux on the smc before attcheed the Stencil? or am i outing too much solder paste? Tried few times but everytime I screwed up and finally did with normal solder this soldering iron which is not the correct way. Anyway thank you very much for all your support louis.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, No green light smc issue?
threads.message: The stencil sticks to the SMC. When you're done, remove the tape, add some flux, heat it at full air with the nozzle further away, and have your tweezers under the stencil. I pop it off that way. The key is to do it in the moment while the balls are slightly expanded down but not fully melted. It will take practice.
